Dr. Lori Desautels, Assistant Professor at Butler's Educational Neuroscience department presented to all staff yesterday during one of our back to school inservice sessions.

Staff learned about ACEs (adverse childhood experiences), brain and body states, intentional focused practices, focused attention practices, touch points and the 4 Universal Growth Needs (belonging, mastery, independence and generosity).

North Newton Schools is working to teach and incorporate social-emotional learning practices in all schools and at all grades. We are also implementing Second Steps curriculum at grades K-8.

Mrs. Kazmierski‘s high school Medical Terminology class dissected cow and sheep hearts yesterday!

During this dissection, students learned about the major blood vessels of the heart and their functions, including taking measurements. Students also demonstrated their knowledge of the four chambers of the heart and the different valves and their location and function. The students were amazed of the difference in size between a cow's heart and a sheep‘s heart. Some of the students even held the heart up to their own chest area to compare just how large a cow's heart is, compared to their own.

The students have been studying the cardiovascular, blood and lymphatic systems. This lab will culminate with students demonstrating their skills by taking blood pressure readings on each other.

A special thanks to Hanford’s Meat Packing for providing us with the cow hearts that were used in this lab!

Mrs. Kazmierski

NN Child Development students have participated in the Reality Works Real Care Baby simulation. This past weekend, the last bunch of students went home with the babies and they got to experience what it is like to care for an infant. These computerized dolls must be fed, burped, rocked, diaper changed, and handled just like a real baby....and all of this is recorded. Babies record temperature, rough handling, and neglect as well.

NN has six of these dolls that are part of the Child Development curriculum. Definitely a hands on, real life experience! Once students complete Child Development and Advanced Child Development, they can take Education Professions or Early Childhood Education during their Junior and/or Senior year as a Pathway.

These higher level courses allow our students to become a Cadet Teacher at our Elementary schools.

Ms. Barb Blasco, Family and Consumer Sciences Teacher

North Newton High School students in Mrs. Kazmierski's Medical Terminology class dissected a cow hide today as part of their study of the Integumetary system lab. Students were tasked with locating the dermis, epidermis, hair follicles, hair root, and sebaceous and sweat glands.

What a great opportunity for each student to get engaged in learning first hand! Critical skills being learned include critical inspection, comparison, keen observation skills and application of knowledge through real world experience!

Cow hide was generously donated by Harry Hanford at Hanford Packing. We love our business partners!

Attendance will be taken by communicating with the teacher in some format.

For additional eLearning information, please visit our website that has several different links on it: https://www.nn.k12.in.us (click on the eLearning tab at the top)

Because of the extreme nature of this winter, the schools will communicate this week how we will address any missed/late eLearning work. Please be safe.
